PD-ENEL (Both images) University of Michigan Histology Collection
[NUMBERED_ITEM] One of the four basic types of tissues (epithelium, connective tissue, muscle, and nervous tissue)
[LIST_ITEM] Bind together and provide mechanical support for other tissue (metabolic, defense, transport, storage)
[LIST_ITEM] most abundant protein in human body (up to 30% dry weight)
[LIST_ITEM] multiple types: fibril-forming or fibril-associated (in skin, tendon, cartilage, bone, dentin, blood vessels); cross-linked networks (in all basement membranes)

[LIST_ITEM] Reticular Fibers – specialized type of collagen (Type III; reticulin) associated with smooth muscle in organs subjected to changes in volume, forms the stroma in lymphatic and hematopoietic organs

[LIST_ITEM] Elastic Fibers – thin fibers or fenestrated sheets composed of various glycoproteins, including the protein elastin, providing elastic properties to tissues that experience repeated deformation (in skin, blood vessels, lung, bladder)
[H1] Major Collagen Fiber Types (out of at least 20).
I (most abundant) | Skin, tendon, bone, dentin | Resistance to tension  | |  II | Cartilage, vitreous of eye | Resistance to pressure  | |  III (reticulin) | Skin, muscle, blood vessels, liver, etc.
| |  IV | All basement membranes | Support and filtration  | |
Fibril-associated collagens with interrupted triple helices (FACIT)
w/ type I and II fibrils
VII | Epithelia | Epidermis to basal lamina  |
[H1] Collagen fibers viewed by light microscopy.
Ross,M, Pawlina, W. Wheater's Functional Histology: A Text and Atlas. Fifth Edition. 2006. Figure 4.2.
© PD-INEL Junquiera and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003.
Alberts et. al. Molecular Biology of the Cell. Second Edition.
Junquiera and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003. Figure 5-19.
[H1] FACIT: Fibril-Associated Collagens with Interrupted Triple helices.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Triple helices interrupted by non-helical domains
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Do not aggregate into large fibrils
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Bind collagen fibrils to each other and/or the ECM
[LIST_ITEM] Binds type II Fibrils to the ECM
[LIST_ITEM] Heparin- $\mathrm{SO}_4$ at kink interacts with ECM
[LIST_ITEM] Helical region interacts with type II fibril
Bundles type I fibrils into FIBERS Binds fibrils via helical domains
Alberts et. al. Molecular Biology of the Cell. Second Edition.
Alberts et. al. Molecular Biology of the Cell. Second Edition.
[LIST_ITEM] Form a delicate supporting framework for highly cellular tissues (endocrine glands, lymph nodes, liver, bone marrow, spleen, smooth muscle).
[LIST_ITEM] Composed mainly of Type III collagen, with a carbohydrate moiety that reduces Ag+ to metallic sliver = argyrophilic
[LIST_ITEM] Special stain: silver impregnation to visualize.
[LIST_ITEM] Thinner than type I collagen (Type III fibrils are 30-40 nm diameter; type I fibrils are ~200 nm diameter)
[LIST_ITEM] made by reticular cells (specialized fibroblasts) and vascular smooth muscle cells
Bottom left and Far right: Source Undetermined
Top left: Ross,M, Pawlina, W. Wheater's Functional Histology: A Text and Atlas. Fifth Edition. 2006.
[H1] Clinical disorders resulting from defects in collagen synthesis.
I | Osteogenesis imperfecta | Spontaneous fractures, progressive hearing loss, cardiac insufficiency
| Hypermobility of digits, early morbidity/mortality from rupture of aorta or intestine  | |  multiple | Scurvy (lack of vit.
C, a cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase) | Ulceration of gums, hemorrhages  |
[LIST_ITEM] A series of genetic diseases with faulty assembly of collagens (lysyl hydroxylase deficiency).
[LIST_ITEM] In some forms (e.g., type IV), weakness in blood vessels or intestines are life threatening.
[H1] Noncollagen Components of the Extracellular Matrix.
LM: Visualized by selectively staining with Weigert's resorcin-fuchsin, or aldehyde-fuchsin
EM: Consist of amorphous core of elastin surrounded by microfibrillar glycoprotein, fibrillin (8-10nm).
Elastin: is rich in glycine and proline, but it contains little or no hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine.
uniquely contains desmosine and isodesmosine, which are thought to cross-link the molecules into a network of randomly coiled chains.
This cross-linking is responsible for its rubber-like properties.
Confers elasticity: present in large amounts in ligaments, lung, skin, bladder, and walls of blood vessels.

Marfan Syndrome: defect in elastic fiber synthesis; reduced elasticity in skin and lungs, skeletal defects (bones are longer and thinner than usual), cardiovascular complications (aneurism, valve prolapse)
[H1] Network of elastin molecules can stretch and recoil like a rubber band.
Alberts et. al. Molecular Biology of the Cell.
[H1] Elastin appears amorphous (not fibrillar) in the electron microscope.
Ross,M, Pawlina, W. Wheater's Functional Histology: A Text and Atlas. Fifth Edition. 2006. Figure 4.4.
M/L=microfibrils of fibrillin, a scaffolding glycoprotein involved elastin deposition
Marfan Syndrome: defect in fibrillin gene, results in weakened elastic fibers
H&E stain: collagen stains orange/pink; elastic fibers stain glassy red (generally only visible if in HIGH abundance)
PD-INEL University of Michigan Histology Collection
elastin stain (“Weigert’s”, “aldehyde fuchsin”, “Verhoeff”): elastic fibers are purple/black
collagen fibers stain orange/pink or blue/green depending on other stains used (von Gieson’s or trichrome, respectively)
[H1] Ground Substance of the Extracellular Matrix (ECM).
[LIST_ITEM] linear (unbranched) polysaccharides, e.g. heparan sulfate, condroitin sulfate, keratan sulfate, hyaluronic acid
[LIST_ITEM] very hydrophilic due to abundant negative charges (e.g. $\mathrm{SO}_4^-$ groups).
[LIST_ITEM] except for hyaluronic acid, are usually bound covalently to protein core as part of a proteoglycan
[LIST_ITEM] core protein + GAG side chains (like a bottle brush)
[LIST_ITEM] bind cells, other proteins, and/or ECM components
[LIST_ITEM] small glycosylated proteins containing NUMEROUS binding sites to cells, signaling molecules, and other ECM components
[LIST_ITEM] e.g. fibronectin and laminin: important for adhesion of epithelial cells to the basal lamina via transmembrane integrin receptors.
© PD-INEL Junquiera and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003. Figure 5-30.
[H1] Basement Membrane – Collagen Types IV, VII, and III.
[LIST_ITEM] Basement membranes are sheets of extracellular matrix proteins located at the interface of parenchyma (epithelia, endothelia, muscle, nerves, adipocytes) and connective tissue / ECM.
[LIST_ITEM] Main constituents are glycosaminoglycans (heparan sulfate), fibrous proteins (collagen types IV, VII, III), structural glycoproteins fibronectin, laminin and entactin.
[LIST_ITEM] This is NOT a plasma membrane.
Thick PD-INEL University of Michigan Histology Collection
[H1] Thin -- requires special stain to visualize.
PD-INEL Ross,M, Pawlina, W. Wheater's Functional Histology: A Text and Atlas. Fifth Edition. 2006. Figure 4.4.
PAS reacts with carbohydrate-rich molecules such as perlecan, laminin and type III collagen associated with the basement membrane.
[H1] Basement Membrane(LM): Three layers in the EM.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Fibroreticular lamina (FL) merges with underlying CT (type III* and type VII collagen fibrils)
*basement membranes can also be visualized with silver stain
So, the “basement membrane” is the basal lamina + the fibroreticular lamina
Interactions of many proteins tether cell to the underlying connective tissue:
Basal lamina to underlying connective tissue:
Free (transient residents) 5. Lymphocytes & Plasma Cells (differentiated B-cells)** 6. "Leukocytes"**
** derived from hematopoietic stem cells and involved in immune function and inflammation
Junqueira and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003.
[H1] Fibroblasts are the most common cells in connective tissue.
[LIST_ITEM] Synthesize and secrete components of the ECM: fibers and ground substance.
[LIST_ITEM] Active and quiescent stages (when quiescent sometimes called fibrocytes or mature fibroblasts).
[LIST_ITEM] Rarely undergo cell division unless tissue is injured, which activates the quiescent cells.
[LIST_ITEM] Play a major role in the process of wound healing and respond to an injury by proliferating and enhanced fiber formation.
Image of active and inactive fibroblasts removed
(Both images) Ross, M. Pawlina, W. Wheater's Functional Histology: A Text and Atlas. Fifth Edition. 2006.
Very active cells with many functions:
[LIST_ITEM] Triglyceride storage and glucose metabolism (insulin and glucagon receptors)
[LIST_ITEM] growth factors (e.g. insulin-like growth factor, tumor necrosis factor α)
Ross, M. Pawlina, W. Wheater's Functional Histology: A Text and Atlas. Fifth Edition. 2006.
White (common, yellow, unilocular) adipose tissue stained with Masson's trichrome
Present in newborns (and hibernating mammals) and involved in thermoregulation
Mitochondria of brown fat cells express uncoupling protein which “short circuits” the electron transport chain producing HEAT rather than ATP.
© PD-INEL Junqueira and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003. Figure 6.4
© PD-INEL Junqueira and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003. Figure 6.3
© PD-INEL Junqueira and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003. Figure 6.5
[H1] Monocytes escape from blood vessels into connective tissue where they differentiate into Macrophages.
Primary function: phagocytosis and antigen presentation
[H1] Plasma Cells are mature B lymphocytes that constitutively secrete antibodies.
© PD-UNEL University of Michigan Histology Collection
© PD-UNEL Junqueira and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003. Figure 6.5.
Black arrows indicate several plasma cells
PD-THEL Junqueira and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003. Figure 5.10.
Metachromasia – when stained with toluidine blue, the granules bind the dye and change its color to red.
[LIST_ITEM] Principal function is storage in secretory granules and REGULATED release (degranulation) of histamine and other vasoactive mediators of inflammation.
[LIST_ITEM] Responsible for the immediate hypersensitivity response characteristic of allergies, asthma and anaphylactic shock.
[LIST_ITEM] Connective tissue mast cells are found in skin (dermis) and peritoneal cavity mucosal mast cells are in the mucosa of the digestive and respiratory tracts.
Junqueira and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003. Figure 5.11.
Junqueira and Carneiro. Basic Histology. Tenth Edition. 2003. Figure 5.12.
[LIST_ITEM] Enter connective tissue from blood vessels as the "first wave" in acute inflammatory responses
[LIST_ITEM] Small cells with multi-lobed, heterochromatic nuclei (aka "polymorphonuclear neutrophils", "PMNs", "polys")
[LIST_ITEM] Primary function: anti-bacterial (are phagocytic like mphages, but SHORT-lived and NOT antigen presenting)
Loose (areolar) connective tissue – delicate, vascularized, cellular; supports the epithelia of the major organs and glands and fills the space between muscle tissue.
Dense connective tissue (many more fibers than cells)
[LIST_ITEM] Dense irregular: meshwork of coarse fibers; dermis of skin, organ capsules, fascia - resists multi-directional forces
[LIST_ITEM] collagenous: fibers aligned in defined pattern; tendons, ligaments, etc. - resists linear mechanical stresses
Adipose - fat storage, glucose regulation, satiety
Reticular - argyrophilic fibers of type III collagen - forms stroma of highly cellular organs (e.g. liver, lymph nodes, spleen)
delicate, vascularized, flexible; facilitates transport of cells and materials (secretion, absorption, immunity)
© PD-INEL University of Michigan Histology Collection small intestine lamina propria
© PD-INEL University of Michigan Histology Collection mammary gland intralobular connective tissue
Densely packed collagen fibers, often in perpendicular bundles; resists tension in many directions and provides mechanical support.
[H1] Dermis of Skin has both Loose and Dense Irregular CT.
© PD-INEI University of Michigan Histology Collection
Adipose tissue in mesentery; tang=adipocyte sectioned tangentially
Liver: slide 198 odd, silver stain, 40x obj
At the end of this session, you should be able to:
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Describe the functions and identify the cells commonly found in connective tissue.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Recognize interstitial (fibrillar) collagens and elastic fibers at the light and electron microscopic levels.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Distinguish between elastic, type I collagen, type III (reticular) collagen, and elastic fibers when appropriately stained material is presented.

[NUMBERED_ITEM] Use knowledge about the physical characteristics of collagen and elastin in explaining the functions of tissue where these molecules occur in large quantities (e.g., coarse type I collagen fibrils present in dense connective tissue compared to more delicate type III fibers found closer to the interface of cells and the extracellular matrix).
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Recognize types of connective tissue (e.g., dense irregular, dense regular, loose, adipose) and provide examples where different types of connective tissue are found in the body.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Recognize a basement membrane (or basal lamina) in sections or micrographs where the structure is conspicuously present and understand its functions.
